releasenotes/notes/unplug-vifs-in-resize.message:
This is too implementation specific. Release notes are for the deployers who might not familiar with what confirm_resize and resize_instance means. I would rephrase this to something like:

... will fail during confirming the resize. The issue is caused by the VIF unplug that happened during the resize confirm action on the source host when the original backend information of the VIF was not available. Please refer to the bug report in the release notes.

/COMMIT_MSG.message:
If people start turning ANSI on then the raw logs end up looking like

https://zuul.opendev.org/t/openstack/build/b4655eb004d143379d424fd968c2e196/log/job-output.txt#637

since the raw logs are the things sent through things like logstash for parsing, it doesn't seem like this is an improvement

This change doe NOT change the log format in any way.

How logs are processed is unrelated to this change and stripping ANSI out when uploading is one of the easiest logstash filters possible.

mutate {
  gsub => ["message", "\x1B\[([0-9]{1,2}(;[0-9]{1,2})?)?[m|K]", ""]
}

AFAIK, At this moment Zuul is the *only* CI/CD system that does not correctly display ANSI correctly.

In fact it does display ANSI in live/streaming console, that being the only place where it already works but most users do not even known about it.

I really hope we are not going down a path that does prefer to cripple the UX -> so less people use the service -> we avoid scalability issues.

I do understand this doesn't change the logs.  but it does encourage everyone to add "--color" or whatever to everything.

fwiw i don't think github/travis ci gets this all that right either ... when I look at

https://github.com/pyca/cryptography/pull/5404/checks?check_run_id=1029159745

going through the pull down boxes it sends my cpu fans spinning and takes well into double digit seconds to render ... to view a log extract.  The raw contents are basically useless because of interactive spinners i guess; e.g.

https://pipelines.actions.githubusercontent.com/hvVe09l57RGA3Cm7JL4sgPbWx7zV70eaczPXXeApNFapxvX30z/_apis/pipelines/1/runs/989/signedlogcontent/4?urlExpires=2020-08-27T10%3A07%3A06.0264012Z&urlSigningMethod=HMACV1&urlSignature=78LvvSsc6uUWnRm%2F87Sw1oJfofNA6pqsNPQ1N7QmZkw%3D

i'm not -1 but it's not a compelling experience all round

I like the idea and it would be nice to have it, but the raw logs having ANSI codes does suck a bit.

Is there a way to filter the ANSI from the raw logs before they get written to disk?

Alternatively perhaps this should be an opt-in feature.

In fact this option has nothing to do with the "logs" (aka zuul artifacts).

This is about displaying/rendering stdout/stdeerr output of ansible tasks, like shell/command.

How we display archived logs and if is good or not to drop ANSI from them, is another subject, outside this change (and likely something configurable).

multus-config/centos/multus-config.spec.message: I don't think this Requires is needed
Not necessary, since it does nothing

This mechanism is needed for overriding a config file installed by a thirdparty. You don't need to do that here. You can install your file directly to %{_sysconfdir}/logrotate.d/multus.logrotate, as you're adding a new file - not replacing an existing one.

Given that, I'm not sure config-files is the right repo for it, but I don't see any multus packages that this config file could belong to, so I'm not going to ask for it to be moved... unless there's an existing package it can be part of?

The original intent of the config-files repo was for custom packages associated with an external thirdparty package, providing a mechanism for installing custom starlingx config files over the original packaged files. Currently, all packages in this repo fall into this category.

This one feels like it's borderline... it's a config file for external thirdparty software, but it's not a replacement of an existing file. So I'm honestly on the fence about whether to keep this here or to move it to one of the more "internal" repos. In which case, you might as well leave it here.

So the change in packaging here would be to install directly to %{_sysconfdir}/logrotate.d/multus.logrotate at line 30 and drop the %post.

Unfortunately multus doesn't really have it's own package - it's completely handled in ansible-playbooks, which creates the k8s manifest files and applies them.

I suppose that the only other suitable option would be to have ansible also create the logrotate configuration files. Do you think that would be preferred?

I have a question about this function.
Why not use 'rbd import' command in this function?

If using 'image.write' for image file in raw format (sparse file) block by block, the rbd device in images pool is very large, and its size is equal to 'virtual size' of image file.
But if we use 'rbd import' for image file in raw format, the rbd device in imgaes pool is very small, and its size is equal to 'disk size' of image file, and the upload  speed is fast.

https://review.opendev.org/#/c/745392/4/glance/tests/functional/v2/test_images_import_locking.py@295

Can you assert the actual sizes used here so that it's easier to visually confirm that it looks like we expect?

 resize.assert_has_calls([mock.call(123), mock.call(246), ...])

That would help catch something in the future where the incrementing was broken by a refactor. It also helps verify that the resize-at-end actually gets called with what you expect.

Also here, my thought was that there should be one less write than resize, and it wasn't clear until I read the code again why that wasn't the case. Might be more obvious and durable if this included details about the writes themselves, which is fairly easy to do (untested, but close):

  # 56MiB in 8MiB chunks and one more after that to make 57MiB
  chunk = 8 * units.Mi
  expected = [(self.data_len / chunk) * units.Mi] + [(self.data_len % chunk) * units.Mi]
  actual = [len(args[0]) for args, kwargs in write.call_args_list]
  self.assertEqual(expected, actual)

manifests/type/gating/shared/catalogues/.message: This is a good trick.  What are your thoughts on the tradeoff between doing this, vs deleting the catalogue after its used?  One the one hand I assume the no-op function takes a bit longer to run, which might pile up as we get more catalogues(?), but it's arguably cleaner?

So thinking about this a little bit more, and being more specific:

The catalogue with no-op krm functions will only "slow things down" when they're interpreted as plugin configs, i.e., when rendering the <site>/<cluster>/<phase>/hostgenerator kustomizations.  Other instances of catalogues will just be "regular resources" and won't invoke the container function.

I expect the slowness to scale linearly with the number of catalogues that are included in those hostgenerator kustomizations.  There are four today (networking, versions, env-vars, hosts), and although I expect we'll add more, I don't think we'll add very many more (to airshipctl).

So: if rendering hosts using the no-op's is "fast enough" today, I expect it won't get too much slower in the future, right?  So, how much do the no-op's slow things down today, do you know?
It'll definitely slow down document bundle building process so I've replace this approach with strategic merge patch

Same problem would be for my other colleagues who use work macbooks with docker for mac software.

I would suggest to change this build process to docker multi-stage build [0]. In Dockerfile you would have 2 stages, first one would be 'builder', something like

  FROM golang:x.x.x AS builder

And on this Makefile 'build:' target you would run something like:

  docker build --target builder --network=host \
	    --build-arg MAKE_TARGET=$(DOCKER_MAKE_TARGET) \
	    --tag $(DOCKER_IMAGE) .
  docker cp $(DOCKER_IMAGE):/path/to/binary .

[0] https://docs.docker.com/develop/develop-images/multistage-build/#use-multi-stage-builds

 The convert tool will migrate your existing JSON-formatted
 policy file to YAML in a backward-compatible way.

?

It would be really helpful to have sample text for this because it's difficult to describe what this means at the (for example) Cinder project level.  It's clear that oslo can deprecate and remove JSON policy file generation, but given that YAML is a superset of JSON, an operator can still give Cinder a policy file full of JSON and it will work just fine. releasenotes/notes/fix-drives-conversion.message:
Why do we allow virtual volumes to sue disks when it changes its RAID?

I agree with the calculation and logic of this implementation.

Certain RAID controllers, such as the PERC H730P, manage physical disks modally. Physical disks are in either JBOD or RAID mode. For such controllers, the physical disks must be in RAID mode when a request to create a RAID virtual disk backed by them is made.

The creation cleaning step selects the physical disks before ensuring they are in RAID mode and converting those which are not. The available physical disk free space reported by the iDRAC depends on the mode and differs between the two modes. Mode conversion can take substantial time to complete, including a reboot.

For this corner case, the implemented solution trades off a small difference between the requested and actual size of the RAID logical disk for a better user experience.
